title: Trump awards posthumous pardon to WWII scientist Zay Jeffries
text:
Donald Trump has awarded a posthumous pardon to leading metal scientist Zay Jeffries

Donald Trump has awarded a posthumous pardon to a leading metal scientist whose work helped secure an Allied victory in World War II.

The White House announced on Thursday that Trump was granting clemency to Zay Jeffries, who grew up in Fort Pierre, South Dakota.

He helped develop artillery shells capable of piercing the armor of German tanks and also consulted on the Manhattan Project, which produced the first atomic bomb.

In a statement, the White House described Jeffries as someone 'crucial to the United States war effort in World War II'.

'His efforts enabled the United States to develop artillery shells capable of piercing the armor of German tanks, and his contributions to the Manhattan Project helped end the war in the Pacific theater,' a spokesperson said.

'When the Department of Justice returned to the case in 1947, it grounded its legal theory on a Supreme Court precedent that did not exist when Dr Jeffries was originally indicted'.

The White House announced on Thursday that Trump (pictured on Thursday) was granting clemency to Jeffries, who grew up in Fort Pierre, South Dakota

Jeffries was indicted in 1941 on antitrust charges related to his employment, but top defense officials asked for his prosecution to be delayed until after the war.

He was convicted and fined $2,500 in 1948 - the same year that President Harry S. Truman awarded him the Presidential Medal for Merit.

The White House said the case has now 'attracted support' from Senator Lindsey Graham and former Congressman Trey Gowdy among others.

'In light of these facts, and in recognition of his contributions to helping to secure an Allied victory in the Second World War, the President has concluded that Dr. Zay Jeffries is worthy of a posthumous pardon', the statement said.

Jeffries studied for a BSc in mining engineering at the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology in 1911 before undertaking an MSc in metallurgical engineering.

He was later awarded a Doctor of Science degree from Harvard University, and went on to become an elected member of the National Academy of Sciences 1939.

Jeffries, who died in 1965, was also awarded the John Fritz Medal for 'outstanding scientific or industrial achievements' in 1946.
description: The White House announced on Thursday that Donald Trump was granting clemency to Zay Jeffries, a scientist who grew up in Fort Pierre, South Dakota.
